author: Raluca Alexa
text:
Good afternoon,

I do have a question, I failed my first driving test due to driving off 35 mph on countryside(it was a really bad weather and not wanted to take any risks).

Today, I had my second attempt, same route, however I failed because I was driving off 50 mph on countryside and she had to take verbal actions and asked me to low the speed

I can no longer understand and don’t know what speed should I drive in the future, I know it’s 60mph but I have the feeling that will always be a failed, unless I’ll have the same person next time.

Please advise what speed should I drive on countryside?

Many thanks.

text: Great video....although just over 10mins in you talk about not getting marked for not checking your left blind spot, when pulling out from the left, and that only your mirror checks and right blind spot is necessary. author: William Tillman
text:
I'm really happy today, I got my driver's license delivered to my mail. I had my driving test twice and failed both time because I get super anxious!
And I will love to share my steps and tips with y'all. 

Try to focus on increasing your confidence levels. First, if you absolutely cannot control your anxiety like I, taking a few deep breaths usually helps in relaxing. Whether that helps or not, I HIGHLY recommend watching YouTube videos of road test recorded using a dashcam or you pay a professional dmv attorney that can walk you through the process of skipping the test drive to get your license. Are you worried of failing, Are you worried of being in the vehicle with a stranger? Combo of both? Something else? paying an attorney to do that work is just the best way to overcome your worries and get your license like I do. 

Remember

"Practice makes Perfect." 

............and there's nothing to worry about if you did it well on your own!
mments
William Tillman

author: Yasmin Idris
text: I have taken my test 3 times before, once during covid and failed within minutes of the test and the last 2 spaced between 2 months and failed with the minors getting high and the serious/dangerous getting low. I was very anxious in my tests and would always fumble when I knew I can drive and do it well! So when it came to my 4th test, I watched this and the 'show me, tell me' videos a few hours before my test and I PASSED with NO MINORS. It is about having a positive mind space and truly being safe guys. Don't get put off if you don't pass first time, you'll appreciate it more when you pass later. Good luck guys and thanks for your vids!!

author: Ivi S
text: How to deal with idiots on the road? I've joined the dual carriage way from the slip road and the car behind me was tailgating me on the slip road and then joined the dual carriageway at the fist opportunity where the slip road was joining the dual carriageway (and before I did) and was blocking left road and blocking me to join!  My car was on the half of the dual carriageway when I had to go back to the slip road because that idiot was blocking me to join. There was a car behind me,I had to slow down to be able to manage to join the carriageway and thankfully didn't run out of the slip road but just about managed to get on it and thankfully a car behind me joined the carriageway on the second lane. That idiot didnt even flinch. Why can't they not install automatic mandatory video cameras in each car so one can record and send to the police for dangerous driving assault/harassment.

author: The Cajun British Experiment.
text:
Question. I’m an American who’s still got 4 months left before I have to officially take my uk test. I’m already a driver with 23 year’s experience as someone who’s a army veteran I’ve driven in multiple countries, but I’ve also picked up bad habits. I’ve already passed my theory test and now practicing for the test. Long story short I plan on taking the test in my own car as I’ve been told that I can, and since I’m still legal to drive on my U.S license I plan on driving there on my own. Here’s where I’m confused though, first of do you have to have someone with you in my situation? Im aware of having the mirror and L plates for the test as well as the other things to check. What if i fail? That’s the big question. Legally I’m allowed to drive but I’ve just failed the test. 
So all of this has raised my concerns and I can’t find a simple straight answer anywhere. 
Appreciate you videos btw , they have been the most useful yet compared to some. I do plan on taking a few hours with a driving instructor for some refresher lessons before the actual test.

text:
Bare in mind:
In a petrol car the gear must be changed over 2500 rpms and not under 2000. First gear can be changed within 2000 because ia very short and sharp.
 Very big risk of engine dying and much more risk of destroying the engine and clutch. Good luck

author: Lord Papi Darkwing
text:
I had my test last Saturday just gone, and ashamedly to say this, but I didn't pass and the reason might surprise you and have you all p'ing your pants. I exited the centre the wrong way, as in going against the road markings, but here's the thing, this man sat there and let me drive for the whole 45 minutes and knew the entire time that I'd already failed. Jokes aside, you ask yourself if it's nerves or mere assumption that because nothing Is said that you can just keep going, for me it was a bit of both, and despite appearances I'm not the driving disaster I might sound like. 

For once they gave me a bit of encouragement and told me my driving is good, but just to polish up on signalling and following traffic signs a bit more timely, and I got less points than on my last fail, so it's not entirely an unhappy ending and I'm not giving up. But good luck to anyone with their test in the future, don't assume anything from silence, just do your best, and remember what your instructors have taught you. More importantly, don't be afraid to ask questions, you can do it!!

author: Sadshark's Vehement Comics
text: It seems like Britains road rules are much more safe than America. Cops here don't even pull people over if they are going 5-10 mph over the limit, and typically will only penalize you if you are going over 10mph above the limit unless there is inclement weather. People will pass on the highway from quickly disappearing merge lanes--they call it a "suicide lane" here because so many people trying to show off will pass other merging cars from that lane even when there's barely any road left for them to do it. People are racing each other at damn near every stoplight and while they mostly will stop racing once they hit the speed limit, many times they won't and they'll race each other until the next light, rev their engines up at each other and all that. I bet there is a lot less accidents in Britain because of all the rules you guys have and the much slower speed limits.

author: Mrfantasticxx
text: I've had my licence for over a year now and I still come to these kind of videos to make sure I still do the correct thing on the road. There's many times where I can see someone do something that I know is the wrong descision, other day I saw an impatient van driver try to overtake a lorry hauling cargo around a small roundabout unaware that the lorry needed the whole round about to pass, the van almost got pinched on the roundabout. I always try to let people through when I can to keep traffic moving on the other side which is something I think a lot of people don't realise sometimes.

author: Mathew M

author: Tommy
text:
Hi Richard
An informative video with some nice content. There are differences between real life driving and a driving test. However, I personally don't like videos on "how to pass the test", as I believe learning to drive safely is far more important. If you learn correctly, you will pass the test, but passing the test doesn't mean you have learnt to drive correctly. The cat B test is the minimum standard required and is the easiest test the DVSA deliver. We should really be aiming for a higher standard than just passing. I know you mention safety several times, but the heading of the video says it all!
You mentioned coasting (did you realise you were coasting in neutral in your video at 40.25? Tut tut!!!🤣)
 - for a cat B test, as long as control is not really compromised a learner can coast at any speed and will likely not fail because of it.
It is also worth clarifying that you can only go on a motorway with a fully qualified instructor when in a dual controlled car. Trainee instructors are not allowed to take learners on a motorway.
When parking in a bay on a driving test, stopping on the line is still acceptable and correcting will normally receive a driving fault (not a minor). So the pupil may as well leave the car on the line instead of correcting. Why risk making things worse! (Even I’m being test focused now)
I am interested that you failed for using your indicator on a busy road. If this is not allowed, how on earth can you move off from the side of the road at very busy times?
There is nothing wrong with using a “begging signal” if used correctly. I’ve never had anyone fail for this, learners or instructors!
Thank you again for the content and keep it up.

author: Aisu Ryujin Ch.
text:
I passed 1st time a few weeks back. Your videos were very helpful especially tips like how to tell the speed of roads etc. Though for my test I thought I failed 15 minutes in because the Examiner went to break the car. But why I didn't fail is because I also broke at the same time. 

What happened was I was waiting to come out onto a round-about and saw the car coming out from my 1st exit indicating right. Assuming she was coming off where I was coming from. That she would be my shield for a gap to pull out of. The second the cars stopped to let her by I glanced to see where I was going. Started to move off and then glanced back just to make sure to realize the car was doing a full 360 on the round-about. So I had to break sharply but I noticed the examiner did the same thing. I thought I failed so was completely surprised when he told me I passed. When I asked him about it. He said he assumed the same thing I did and would of done the same thing and while yes he did react but because I reacted myself also and broke at the same time. He let it go. 

my nerves shot through the roof thinking I failed but managed to keep it together enough to pass. I thought to myself that I will keep trying my best cause at least then I will know which areas I still need to work on for the next test. Luckily that never happened

author: Ian Morrison
text: I disagree with the information at 10 mins about checking the kerbside blind spot. You shouldn’t move off if there is a pedestrian on the pavement close to the car. You won’t know this if you fail to check this blind spot. My routine: pedestrians move slower than cars, check the pavement blind spot first, road blind spot second, move without delay, if any delay, restart the process.

author: Sush
text: Hey Richard, as a brit who is currently living in Berlin (and never got around to learning to drive in the UK), I am super grateful for all of your extremely informative videos. Of course, not all the road rules and norms are the same here (quite a few are pretty different), but your videos have still helped me immensely in feeling comfortable with the art of driving manual. I passed today on my second attempt, and I can certainly attribute a ton of the credit to your videos! They're sure to continue benefitting me as I learned on a diesel, and I know petrols control a bit differently. Thank you!

He just couldn't get it into his thick skull that practising test routes is like practising past exam papers to improve exam technique. In the end, I ditched him and found a better instructor.

author: Junius Chan
text: damn, the UK driving test is sooo much harder than the Australian one here, we just get around a 45min general drive which covers some easy stuff like right hand onto major roads, roundabouts, tight roads, lane change etc + 5 slow speeds (angle park, moving off, parallel, 3 point and u turn) and we get the luxury of driving in an auto (same license to drive manual) and none of the show me tell me stuff too. But tbf marking system makes it easier to fail

author: JCBarber

I wonder how long it will be before that rule is discreetly removed (even though i think it is good in its intentions) and also how many examiners have failed pupils because they haven't followed the rule correctly. I haven't had a single student pick up a single fault because of this change in the rules so far.

author: AIDAN PEREIRA
text:
(Already passed my test but might give a bike test in few months). For the eyesight test, what happens if you mix up similar letters... like a K can look like R from far, especially when the screw that holds the plate on is on the top centre of the K so from far it looks like an R. Do they let that slide as long as you get the rest or most of the rest correct?

Also for my test i had my wing mirror a bit low and adjusted it while at the stop light within the first 2 minutes of the test... Idk if the examiner noticed or not but is that allowed. Didn't get a minor for it but just curious if I just got lucky that he didnt notice

author: Luke James
text:
36:12 I really need to get a bumper sticker that says this or one of those police matrix boards! The amount of times I get cars undertaking me on motorways because I've got a 2 second gap despite passing traffic on lane 1... well I've lost count, and after they've undertook they gain a whole 50 meter advantage to be stuck behind the car i was following for the next 20 miles... bravo.... It does make me question if these types of people have evolved enough to be even classified as human, let alone drive a motor vehicle. What's worse is you get lorries now flashing their lights if you give the two second gap!

Richard, really would like to get your opinion on this, you know when you're in a high traffic motorway section such as rush hour and for some bizarre reason the traffic speeds up to like 40 and then slams on their brakes back to standstill and then quickly back to 40, do you try and average this out / pace the traffic by leaving a good gap infront so you can say go a steady 20 to avoid the stop start / high acceleration and harsh braking? For me this is a much better solution than going up the gears, accelerating hard, wearing you left foot out, wearing the brakes and reducing fuel economy. (Sorry for the long comment 😅) interesting video as always. Good to keep the old knowledge fresh!

author: Neil Holmes

It had been that long since I'd made such a basic error that I couldn't work out what the noise was until the examiner told me so failed

author: Mr M
text: Love your videos. I have my 2nd test next Monday. I'm incredibly anxious. I keep telling myself that I've got this, but I'm soooooo nervous.

author: Gregory Fenn
text: What do you do if a examiner tells you to go left and later fails you because the left hand lane was a bus lane?

author: Punjabi walaytieya
text: I am learning automatic, no clutch control, no hill start problem, no coasting, no car coming back at up the hill stop , I have test on 12th of December.

author: Tomogochi
text: why do i enjoy watching your videos after i passed my test 10 days ago xD!

author: Scatra1991
text: Hello Richard. I have watched your videos for a while now and definitely credit them for easing my anxiety, increasing my knowledge and helping me pass my test. Unfortunately, despite newly passed I am really struggling driving another car that doesn't have a digital speedometer. I really struggle to gauge my speed and what gear to be in. Any tips for this? I can hear the differences in engine noise as an indicator of changing gear but I didn't use that in my lessons.

author: Grand Admiral Thrawn
text: Just passed my test first time today with 3 minors. Your videos have been a great help on this journey! Thank you!

author: Generic Multidimensional Hypercube
text:
I've got my test in like 16hours, your videos have been so helpful

Update: I PASSED

Update: I just passed my PCV driving test as well.

author: kayleigh wall
text: I passed my test in August this year but am still gonna watch this video, can never stop learning 👍🚘

author: Alteo
text: Please could you do more commentary with you driving with the pedal cam included? There aren’t enough UK driving vids of these sorts. Thank you for all your content.

author: TakeNotice
text: Looking back now and how worried I was about doing lessons and passing my test it was actually quite easy tbh, getting past clutch control and learning round abouts it’s all pretty much straight forward, thanks to your videos anyway, good luck to who ever is worried or to do their test !

author: Kyungsoos Main Hoe
text: i have my driving test at the end of next month. i have anxiety and im absolutely terrified but your videos and my instructor have been so great. im really grateful for what you do, thank youso much for making these videos!

author: Daniel Agostinho
text: 10:50 I can only imagine what you saw there or what was the person on the side of the road doing

author: JazzyJaz
text: My 20 meters was more like 10 lol

author: Pauline Gerst
text: God help me. I chuckled at "safe and legal". Someone get me a therapist 💀💀

author: Terrie Knight
text:
very timely for me. Thanks.
Any chance you could do/ put up more how to teach videos of you doing a lesson on the various skills/subjects please? I find your videos invaluable.

author: John McCall
text: Howdy!
